question: What is the official report that contains everything said in Parliament called?
tip: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard.

question: What did the 'Bill of Rights' confirm?
tip: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

question: What is the capital of Wales?
tip: Cardiff is the capital of Wales.

question: Why was Mary known as 'Bloody Mary'?
options: She put her sister in prison
tip: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants.

question: When is St Andrew's Day?
tip: St Andrew's Day is on the 30th of November.

question: Who is the heir to the throne?
tip: The Queen’s eldest son, Prince Charles (the Prince of Wales), is the heir to the throne.

question: Which of the following is part of the UK?
tip: The United Kingdom consists of Wales,England,Scotland and Northern Ireland.

question: Who established the Church of England?
tip: To divorce his first wife, Henry VIII needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

question: Who built the Tower of London?
tip: The Tower of London was built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066.

question: When did the UK join the EU?
tip: The UK originally decided not to join the EU (European Union) but it became a member in 1973. There are now 28 EU member states.

question: Which tribes invaded Britain after the Romans had left?
tip: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

question: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
tip: The National Anthem of the UK is ‘God Save the Queen’. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: ‘God save our gracious Queen! Long live our noble Queen! God save the Queen! Send her victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the Queen!’.

question: Who is the head of the Church of England?
tip: The monarch is the head of the Church of England. The spiritual leader of the Church of England is the Archbishop of Canterbury.

question: When is Boxing Day?
tip: Boxing Day (26th of December) is the day after Christmas Day (25th of December) and is a public holiday.

question: What term arose after the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
tip: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase ‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

question: What is the judiciary responsible for?
options: Deciding whether a person is guilty
tip: Judges, who are together called ‘the judiciary’, are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

question: What is the ‘Divine Right of Kings?
options: Reduced the power of the King
Reduced the power of the nobles
The King was Appointed by God
tip: ‘Divine Right of Kings’ is the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. The king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

question: Who first introduced James Bond?
tip: Ian Fleming’s books introduced James Bond.

question: What is the responsibility that you have as a UK citizen?
options: Look after yourself and your family
tip: Flowing from the fundamental principles are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK and which we expect all residents to respect.

question: Where does the Scottish Grand National take place?
tip: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

question: How old do you have to be to participate in the National Lottery?
tip: There is a National Lottery for which draws are made every week. You can enter by buying a ticket or a scratch card. People under 16 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery.

question: Who is known as William the Conqueror?
tip: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

question: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690. This event is celebrated in which country?
tip: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

question: The Victoria Cross medal was introduced during which war?
tip: Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during the Crimean war. It honours acts of valour by soldiers.

question: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’.
tip: A constitution is a set of principles by which a country is governed. It includes all of the institutions that are responsible for running the country and how their power is kept in check. The constitution also includes laws and conventions. The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’.

question: Where is the UK geographically located with respect to Europe?
tip: The UK is located in the North-West of Europe.

question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
tip: The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955–), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

question: Which of these is a Crown Dependency of the UK and not a part of it?
tip: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called ‘Crown dependencies’. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

question: Who helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) in 1903?
tip: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU).

question: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by civil servants who are appointed by the Government?
tip: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by democratically elected councils, often called ‘local authorities’. Some areas have both district and county councils, which have different functions. Most large towns and cities have a single local authority.

question: You can contact MPs only at their office in the House of Commons
tip: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons.

question: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. Who did he become?
tip: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury (see the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Church in Britain today).

question: The Union Jack is comprised of four countries’ crosses. They are: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
tip: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack. The flag combined crosses associated with England, Scotland and Ireland. It is still used today as the official flag of the UK.

question: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. What was it called?
tip: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

question: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
tip: Shamrock is associated with Northern Ireland

question: Which Admiral's Column is in Trafalgar Square, London?
tip: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle. Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square, London, is a monument to him. His ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth.

question: Christmas Day, which celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, is on which day?
tip: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday. Many Christians go to church on Christmas Eve (24 December) or on Christmas Day itself.

question: What is the most famous competition which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia?
tip: Cricket originated in England and is now played in many countries. Games can last up to five days but still result in a draw! The idiosyncratic nature of the game and its complex laws are said to reflect the best of the British character and sense of fair play. You may come across expressions such as ‘rain stopped play’, ‘batting on a sticky wicket’, ‘playing a straight bat’, ‘bowled a googly’ or ‘it’s just not cricket’, which have passed into everyday usage. The most famous competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

question: What is the money limit for the small claims procedure in England and Wales?
tip: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £3,000 in Northern Ireland.

question: What did the Queen celebrate in 2012?
tip: Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her Diamond Jubilee in 2012. The clock tower ‘Big Ben’ was named ‘Elizabeth Tower’ in honour of this event.

question: Which two things should you do if you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK?
options: Look after the area in which you live and the environment
Look after yourself and your family
tip:
If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should:
•respect and obey the law
•respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions
•treat others with fairness
•look after yourself and your family
•look after the area in which you live and the environment.

question: Which of the following traditional heavy industries were badly affected during the great depression?
tip: The effects of the depression of the 1930s were felt differently in different parts of the UK. The traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries – including the automobile and aviation industries – developed.

question: Which one of the following is the most famous play written by Shakespeare?
tip: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet.

question: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of what?
tip: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London. It has been organised by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) since 1927. The Last Night of the Proms is the most well-known concert and (along with others in the series) is broadcast on television.

question: After Cromwell defeated Charles II at Worcester, where did Charles II hide?
tip: The Scots had not agreed to the execution of Charles I and declared his son Charles II to be king. He was crowned king of Scotland and led a Scottish army into England. Cromwell defeated this army in the Battles of Dunbar and Worcester. Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

question: Which of the following discoveries contributed to the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
tip: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers. Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

question: What did Sir Frank Whittle invent in the 1930s?
tip: The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle (1907–96), a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.

question: The UK government hasn’t used the power to suspend the Northern Ireland Assembly
tip: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is also a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

question: How often do PM's Questions take place in the parliament?
tip: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government's failures and weaknesses. One important opportunity to do this is at Prime Minister's Questions, which takes place every week while Parliament is sitting.

question: What tells us about how people lived just after the Norman Conquest?
tip: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

question: How can you contact your MP?
tip: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons

question: What is the reason for more ageing population? Choose Two Answers
tip: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

question: Who was the Prime minister and inspiration leader during the World War Two?
tip: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship. He lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.

question: Which film or film franchise produced in UK has been the biggest gross earner?
tip: Many of the films now produced in the UK are made by foreign companies, using British expertise. Some of the most commercially successful films of all time, including the two highest-grossing film franchises (Harry Potter and James Bond), have been produced in the UK.

question: The Man Booker Prize is awarded in which area?
tip: The Man Booker Prize for Fiction is awarded annually for the best fiction novel written by an author from the Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe. It has been awarded since 1968. Past winners include Ian McEwan, Hilary Mantel and Julian Barnes.

question: Pakistan is part of the Commonwealth
tip: Pakistan is currently part of the Commonwealth

question: The queen's eldest son, Prince Charles, is also known as?
tip: The Queen has reigned since her father's death in 1952, and in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as queen). She is married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, Prince Charles (the Prince of Wales), is the heir to the throne.

question: William Orange was asked by Protestants to invade England. This event was later known as what?
tip: James II’s elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands. In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. This event was later called the ‘Glorious Revolution’ because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament.

question: In 1913, the British government promised 'Home Rule' for Ireland, why was this postponed?
options: The Scottish people also wanted to self-govern
The outbreak of World War I
tip: In 1913, the British government promised 'Home Rule' for Ireland. It was opposed by the Protestants in the north of Ireland, who threatened to resist Home Rule by force. The outbreak of the First World War led the British government to postpone any changes in Ireland. Irish Nationalists were not willing to wait and in 1916 there was an uprising (the Easter Rising) against the British in Dublin. A guerilla war against the British army and the police in Ireland followed. In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries.

question: What lead the American colonies to declare their independence?
options: The UK not providing enough health care
The UK wanting to tax the colonies
The UK wanting to stop the slave trade
The UK not sending enough money
tip: By the 1760s, there were substantial British colonies in North America. The colonies were wealthy and largely in control of their own affairs. Many of the colonist families had originally gone to North America in order to have religious freedom. They were well educated and interested in ideas of liberty. The British government wanted to tax the colonies.

question: Which TWO religions celebrate Diwali?
tip: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

question: When did the English settlers first begin to colonise the eastern coast of America?
tip: In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America. This colonisation, particularly by people who disagreed with the religious views of the next two kings, greatly increased in the next century.

question: Name the most famous cricket competition, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia
tip: The most famous competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

question: Queen Elizabeth I was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants
tip: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as ‘Bloody Mary’). Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

question: Whom did the serfs serve?
tip: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism. The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war. Landowners had to send certain numbers of men to serve in the army. Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.

question: Which battle did William the Conqueror fight in?

question: Where is the Millennium Stadium located?

question: What was the longest British War with France called?

The English left France in the 1450s.

question: What is the Cenotaph associated with?
tip: After the First World War, Sir Edwin Lutyens was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen, politicians and foreign ambassadors

question: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy
tip: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government. If one party does not get a majority, two parties can join together to form a coalition.

question: What character did Charlie Chaplin play?
tip: Sir Charles (Charlie) Chaplin became famous in silent movies for his tramp character and was one of many British actors to make a career in Hollywood.

question: What was Isaac Newton famous for?
tip: His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica (‘Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy’), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe. Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow. Many of his discoveries are still important for modern science.

question: Where are the minor criminal cases dealt with in England, Wales and N. Ireland?
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates’ Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

question: Who ran 1 mile in 4 minutes in 1954?
tip: Sir Roger Bannister (1929–) was the first man in the world to run a mile in under four minutes, in 1954.

question: The BBC is controlled by the UK government
tip: The BBC is the largest broadcaster in the world. It is the only wholly state-funded media organisation that is independent of government. Other UK channels are primarily funded through advertisements and subscriptions.

question: Women over 30 were allowed to vote as a result of their contribution towards the war effort. Which war was it?
tip: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War. Shortly before Emmeline’s death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

question: What's the objective of the Commonwealth?
options: Achieve goals in democracy and development
Allow visa free migration across the member states
tip: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

question: How can you arrange to get a National Insurance number?
options: Contact the Department for Work and Pensions
tip: If you have permission to work in the UK, you will need to telephone the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to arrange to get a National Insurance number.

question: Which TWO of the athletes are paralympians?

question: What’s the Queen’s speech for?

Give advise to the general public
Summarise all of the previous policies
Set out the government's legislative plans for the next year
tip: The Queen has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Queen makes a speech which summarises the government’s policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in her name.

question: Nick Park created the ‘Wallace and Gromit’ film. What kind of film was it?

question: Admiral Nelson died in which battle?

question: What should you do to make a complaint about the Police?
options: Write to the Chief Constable of the Police force
Write a complaint letter to the House of Commons
Complain to the Police force directly

question: Can the anthem ‘God save the queen’ be played only in presence of the Queen?

question: Which is a famous area in London for theatres?
tip: There are theaters in most towns and cities throughout the UK, ranging from the large to the small. The Mousetrap, a murder-mystery play by Dame Agatha Christie, has been running in the West End since 1952 and has had the longest initial run of any show in history.

question: Which comedy double act by Nick Park won many Oscars?
tip: Nick Park, who has won four Oscars for his animated films, including three for films featuring Wallace and Gromit.

question: What is a good way to support your local community?
options: Shop for products locally where you can
tip: A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

question: Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. What was this known as?
tip: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

question: Where was Rudyard Kipling born?
tip: Rudyard Kipling was born in India in 1865 and later lived in India, the UK and the USA. He wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

question: Wales and Scotland use a system called 'individual registration'.All those entitled to vote must complete their own registration forms
tip: In Northern Ireland a system called 'individual registration' operates and all those entitled to vote must complete their own registration form. Once registered, people stay on the register provided their personal details do not change.

question: In 1745, who was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army?
tip: In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I’s son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army. Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II’s army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746. Charles escaped back to Europe.

question: What country did Hitler invade in 1939?
tip: The British government tried to avoid another war. However, when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

question: Who is Sir Edward Elgar(1857-1934)?
tip: Sir Edward Elgar (1857–1934) was born in Worcester, England. His best-known work is probably the Pomp and Circumstance Marches. March No 1 (Land of Hope and Glory) is usually played at the Last Night of the Proms at the Royal Albert Hall.

question: What are traditional pub games? (Select TWO)
tip: Most communities will have a ‘local’ pub that is a natural focal point for social activities. Pub quizzes are popular. Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

question: In year 1066, William the Conqueror invaded England in which battle?

The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

question: What was the name of the movement which protested against the Roman Catholic church during Henry VIII's time?
tip: During Henry III's reign, the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

question: Where are all minor criminal cases heard in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates’ Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

question: Complaints against the Police can only be made by writing to the Police Complaints Commissioner
tip: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to an independent body: the Independent Police Complaints Commission in England and Wales, the Police Complaints Commissioner for Scotland or the Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland.

question: Every MP in the UK has his/her own constituency
tip: Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government.

question: National Trust is a charity that works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside
tip: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

question: Which of the statements is true?
options: Solicitors' charges are based on how serious the case is
Solicitors' charges are based on how much time they spend on a case

question: Who appoints the government, which most people have chosen in a democratic election?

question: In Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic

question: What is the BBC funded by?
tip: Money from TV licences goes to the BBC.

question: How often are the European Parliament elections held?

question: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development
tip: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

question: What’s the age requirement to drink wine with a meal with someone over 18?
tip: 16 year olds can drink wine or beer with a meal in a hotel or restaurant as long as they are with someone over 18.

question: When was the Scottish Parliament formed?
tip: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999.

question: In England and Wales, the small claims procedure is used for claims of less than what amount?
tip: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £3,000 in Northern Ireland.

question: What does the money raised from National Insurance Contributions pay for? (Choose TWO)
tip: The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

question: The leader of the Opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election
tip: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition. The leader of the opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

question: When was the first public film shown in the UK?
tip: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular. From the beginning, film makers became famous for clever special effects and this continues to be an area of British expertise.

question: What food is traditionally associated with Wales?

tip: You must pay for a licence to watch TV through any medium.

tip: One TV licence covers all of the equipment at one address, but people who rent different rooms in a shared house must buy a separate TV licence

tip: The conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the British government is often referred to as ‘the Troubles’.

question: There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay for a vet
tip: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

question: After the Black Death, a new social class appeared, - owners of large areas of land. What were they called?
tip: New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land called 'the gentry', and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

question: In what year was Germany comprehensively defeated by the Allies during the WWII?
tip: Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France and eventually into Germany. The Allies comprehensively defeated Germany in May 1945.

question: What will happen to any driver who has either taken more than the acceptable quantity of alcohol or refused to take the test?
tip: If you are found driving while exceeding the alcohol limit you will be arrested.

question: Who developed ideas about economics during the Enlightenment period which are still referred to today?
tip: Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. question: People of the Iron Age sometimes defended sites. What were these sites?
tip: People still lived in roundhouses, grouped together into larger settlements, and sometimes defended sites called hill forts. A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

question: You can find copies of Hansard report in large libraries and on the Internet
tip: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be found in large libraries and online.

question: The Prime Minister is the head of the Commonwealth
tip: The Queen is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 54 member states.

question: What percentage of the UK population lives in England?
tip: England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

question: When did hereditary peers lose the automatic right to attend the House of Lords?
tip: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

question: Hanukkah is celebrated to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom and it is in November or December for how many days?
tip: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom. question: The leader of the Opposition appoints senior opposition MPs to be what?

tip: April Fool’s Day, 1 April, is a day when people play jokes on each other until midday. The television and newspapers often have stories that are April Fool jokes.

tip: You can get details about the small claims procedure from your local County Court or Sheriff Court.

tip: More serious civil cases – for example, when a large amount of compensation is being claimed – are dealt with in the High Court in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. In Scotland, they are dealt with in the Court of Session in Edinburgh.

question: In what year did the Troubles break out?

question: How many counties in Ireland remained in the UK under Northern Ireland?

question: Who wrote music for George VI and Queen Elizabeth II?

question: Who wrote about their experiences in the First World War?
tip: Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon – were inspired to write about their experiences in the First World War.

question: Where does the Grand National takes place?

question: The House of Lords is more independent of the government
tip: The House of Lords is normally more independent of the government than the House of Commons. It can suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by MPs. The House of Lords checks laws that have been passed by the House of Commons to ensure they are fit for purpose.

question: Who should you contact to get your National Insurance number?

tip: Many of the painters working in Britain in the 16th and 17th centuries were from abroad – for example, Hans Holbein and Sir Anthony Van Dyck.

tip: Protestant Christian groups in the UK are Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians and Quakers. There are also other denominations of Christianity, the biggest of which is Roman Catholic.

tip: The Council of Europe is separate from the EU. It has 47 member countries, including the UK, and is responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in those countries. tip: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections. Adult citizens of other EU states who are resident in the UK can vote in all elections except General Elections.

question: How is the Speaker elected?

tip: The Speaker keeps order during political debates to make sure the rules are followed. This includes making sure the opposition (see The government) has a guaranteed amount of time to debate issues which it chooses. The Speaker also represents Parliament on ceremonial occasions.

tip: The Human Rights Act 1998 incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law. The government, public bodies and the courts must follow the principles of the Convention.

tip: In England, judges developed ‘common law’ by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition. In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were ‘codified’ (that is, written down).

tip: Divine Right of Kings' is the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. The king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

question: The small claims procedure in Northern Ireland is used for claims of less than what amount?
tip: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £3,000 in Northern Ireland.

question: The Bill of Rights confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the King's power
tip: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

question: Which TWO words appear in the first two lines of the national anthem 'God save the Queen'?
tip: The first verse is: 'God save our gracious Queen! Long live our noble Queen! God save the Queen! Send her victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the Queen!'.

question: Where can you visit Admiral Nelson's ship , HMS Victory?
tip: Admiral Nelson's ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth

question: The King James' Bible is a new translation of the Bible into English
tip: One achievement of King James' reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'. It was not the first English Bible but is a version which continues to be used in many Protestant churches today.

question: The Corn Laws were repealed in 1846. This had prevented the import of cheap grain
tip: The statement is true.

question: Mary Stuart (also known as 'Mary, Queen of Scots') fled to England. She was suspected of trying to take over the throne and was kept a prisoner for 20 years
tip: The statement is true.

question: Constituencies which had hardly any voters were called 'Pocket Boroughs'
tip: Some constituencies were controlled by a single wealthy family. These were called 'pocket boroughs'. Other constituencies had hardly any voters and were called 'rotten boroughs'.

question: The process 'Highland Clearances' happened due to rebellion of slaves
tip: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

question: The Scottish Parliament (after the Magna Carta was established in England) was split into two estates: the Lords and the Commons
tip: In England, the nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons. Only a small part of the population was able to join in electing the members of the Commons. In Scotland, the parliament had three Houses, called Estates: the Lords, the Commons and the Clergy.

question: Oliver Cromwell took the title 'King of Ireland'
tip: Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658. Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'

question: When William of Orange re-conquered Ireland (in 1690) he took the title 'William the Conqueror'
tip: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

question: What does St Patrick's cross look like?
options: A red cross on a white ground
A diagonal red cross on a white ground
A diagonal white cross on a blue ground
tip: The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground; The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground; The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

question: The British constitution is described as 'unwritten'
tip: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government. Our most important institutions have developed over hundreds of years.

question: In Scotland, judges developed 'common law' by following previous decisions. It was referred to as 'unwritten'
tip: In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition. In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were 'codified' (that is, written down).

question: In 2003, The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best loved novel
tip: In 2003, The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best loved novel

question: People don't celebrate Christmas as much as they used to before
tip: Christmas remains very popular in the UK. People usually spend the day at home and eat a special meal, which often includes roast turkey, Christmas pudding and mince pies.

question: What is the minimum age for going into betting shops or gambling clubs?
tip: You have to be 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

question: Henry VIII's fourth wife, Anne of Cleves was a Spanish princess
tip: Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.

question: Only members of the public who have their name on the electoral register can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster in the House of Lords
tip: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

question: The Restoration' refers to the reestablishment of Roman Catholicism
tip: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland. Charles II made it clear that he had 'no wish to go on his travels again'. There was a restoration of the monarchy.

question: Sir Kingsley Amis was a famous English novelist and poet who wrote more than 20 novels, including 'Lucky Jim'
tip: Sir Kingsley Amis (1922-95) was an English novelist and poet. He wrote more than 20 novels. The most well-known is Lucky Jim.

question: Those who don't respect the law should not expect to be allowed to become permanent residents
tip: If you don't respect the law you should not expect to be allowed to settle in the UK

question: Sir Edward Elgar is known for his famous music work - 'The Planets'
tip: More recently, important composers include Gustav Holst (1874-1934), whose work includes The Planets, a suite of pieces themed around the planets of the solar system. He adapted Jupiter, part of the Planets suite, as the tune for I vow to thee my country, a popular hymn in British churches.

question: Big Ben was named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth I
tip: Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the Houses of Parliament in London. Many people call the clock Big Ben as well. The clock is over 150 years old and is a popular tourist attraction. The clock tower is named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

question: Queen Mary was a Protestant and persecuted Catholics (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary')
tip: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary'). Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

question: The jury decides whether a person is 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard
tip: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of 'not proven' is also possible. If the jury finds a defendant guilty, the judge decides on the penalty. The judge is only responsible for interpreting the law.

question: You should respect someone's right in court. In return, you are offered the right to a fair trial.
tip: You should always respect everyone rights in court. Vise versa everyone should respect your rights.

question: Great Britain' and 'the United Kingdom' have the same meaning
tip: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

question: Wales wasn't under Anglo-Saxon rule
tip: Parts of the west of Britain, including much of what is now Wales, and Scotland, remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule.

question: The Welsh Dragon doesn't appear on the Union Flag because Wales was already united with England in 1606
tip: The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.

question: The Opposition is the second largest party in the House of Commons
tip: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the Opposition. The leader of the Opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

question: David Hockney was an important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s
tip: David Hockney (1937-) was an important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s and continues to be influential today.

question: During Queen Elizabeth's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world had ever seen
tip: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

question: The Speaker is an MP, he/she represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP
tip: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP.

question: Catherine Howard was Anne Boleyn's cousin
tip: Catherine was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

question: Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to
tip: Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to. It reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God. Many Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat during this festival. In Britain this has to be done in a slaughterhouse.

question: Which of the following is a William Wordsworth's poem?
tip: All 4 options are poems, but all written by different poets.(Robert Browning, 1812-89 'Home Thoughts from Abroad'), (Lord Byron, 1788-1824 'She Walks in Beauty'), (William Blake, 1757-1827 'The Tyger'), (William Wordsworth, 1770-1850 'The Daffodils' - 'I wander'd lonely as a cloud, That floats on high o'er vales and hills, When all at once I saw a crowd, A host of golden daffodils').

question: It is compulsory to join National Citizen Service programme for 16 and 17 year olds
tip: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

question: The band called Beatles was popular and some alteration to social laws occurred during which period?
tip: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as 'the Swinging Sixties'. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. It was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland. The position of women in the workplace also improved.

question: Where are all minor criminal cases heard in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

question: Can the anthem 'God save the queen' be played only in presence of the Queen?
tip: You can play the Anthem in anyone's presence

question: What's the Queen's speech for?
options: Set out the government's legislative plans for the next year
Summarise all of the previous policies
Give advice to the general public
Encourage the youth to persuade education
tip: The Queen has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Queen makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in her name.

question: What is the geographic position of the UK in Europe?
tip: The UK is located in the North West of Europe.

question: The Queen's eldest son, Prince Charles, is also known as?
tip: The Queen has reigned since her father's death in 1952, and in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as queen). She is married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, Prince Charles (the Prince of Wales), is the heir to the throne.

question: In England & Wales, the small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes claims of less than?
tip: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £3,000 in Northern Ireland.

question: Why is 1918 an important date in the history of women's rights?
options: The first divorce laws were introduced.
Women were given the right to vote.
Women were made legally responsible for their children.
tip: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given the right to vote. In 1928, women were given the right to vote at 21, the same age as men.

question: British scientists were the first to clone a mammal successfully. The animal was a rabbit.
tip: The British team used a sheep for the first mammal cloning. The sheep was called Dolly.

question: There is a dragon on the official flag of Wales.
tip: Wales has its own flag, which includes a dragon. The Welsh flag is not a part of the Union Flag, as Wales had united with England many years before the Union Flag was designed.

question: 'The Restoration' refers to the re-establishment of Catholicism as the official Church in the 17th century.
tip: The Restoration' refers to the re-establishment of the monarchy in 1660, when Charles II returned from exile after being invited back by Parliament.

question: The Union Flag comprises four crosses, one for each part of the United Kingdom.
tip: The Union Flag comprises three crosses – the crosses of St George (England), St Andrew (Scotland) and St Patrick (Ireland).

question: Why was Magna Carta important?
options: It gave all men the vote.
It limited the power of the monarch.
It established a system of free education.
tip: King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to the Magna Carta, which restricted the power of the monarchy.

question: Which TWO are plays by William Shakespeare?
tip: Among the many plays that Shakespeare wrote are A Midsummer Night's Dream and Romeo and Juliet.

question: In 1805 at the Battle of Trafalgar, Admiral Nelson defeated the German fleet.
tip: At the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805 Admiral Nelson defeated a combined French and Spanish fleet. He was killed during the battle.

question: Wales united with England during the reign of Henry VIII.
tip: By the Act for the Government of Wales during the reign of King Henry VIII, Wales united with England.

question: In 1348 a third of the populations of England, Wales and Scotland died as a result of which plague?
tip: The vast number of people who died from the Black Death led to changes in the way society was structured. For example, new social classes appeared, including large landowners, and labour shortages meant that peasants demanded higher wages.

question: Florence Nightingale is famous for her work on children's education in the 19th century.
tip: Florence Nightingale (1820–1910) was famous for her work to improve the quality of nursing and hospital conditions. She is often considered the founder of modern nursing.

question: Which of the following is a famous Stone Age site in the UK?
tip: Stonehenge is a famous Stone Age site in Wiltshire. It was probably built as a place for religious ceremonies.

question: Textile and engineering firms recruited workers from which TWO countries after the Second World War?
tip: Textile and engineering firms from the north of England and the Midlands sent agents to India and Pakistan to recruit workers.

question: Isaac Newton is a famous musician from the 18th century.
tip: Isaac Newton was a famous scientist who developed our understanding of gravity.

question: A public vote in 2002 decided that Winston Churchill was the Greatest Briton of all time.
tip: In 2002 Winston Churchill (1874–1965), the British Prime Minister from 1940 until 1945, was voted the Greatest Briton of all time by the British public.

question: Why was the Habeas Corpus Act of 1679 so important?
options: It ensured no person could be imprisoned unlawfully.
It allowed people to bury the dead where they wished.
It ensured that those who died could only be buried by a relative.
It ended capital punishment in England.
tip: The Habeas Corpus Act was a major legal development ensuring that people could not be held prisoner without just cause.

question: The jet engine and radar were developed in Britain in the 1830s.
tip: The jet engine and the radar were both developed in Britain in the 1930s.

question: What did St Augustine and St Columba do during the Anglo-Saxon period?
options: They were leaders of an uprising in Wales.
tip: St Augustine and St Columba were early Christian missionaries who came to Britain to preach about Christianity. St Columba founded a monastery on the Isle of Iona. St Augustine spread Christianity in the south and became the first archbishop of Canterbury.

question: During the 18th century, radical new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed, called 'the Enlightenment'.
tip: The period of the Enlightenment saw many new ideas emerge, including the principle that everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them.

question: Which TWO of the following were famous Victorians?
tip: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806–59) was a famous engineer, and Florence Nightingale (1820–1910) established a training school for nurses, the first of its kind.

question: What were TWO important aspects of the Reform Act of 1832?
options: It decreased the power of the monarch.
It increased the number of people who could vote.
tip: The Reform Act of 1832 increased the number of men who could vote. It also abolished many rotten boroughs (parliamentary seats where there were few voters), and increased the number of seats in the new cities and towns.

question: Emmeline Pankhurst is famous for her leadership of the campaign to give women the vote in parliamentary elections in the UK.
tip: Emmeline Pankhurst (1858–1928) was the leader of the women's suffrage movement that campaigned for women to be given the vote. Her supporters were called 'suffragettes'.

question: For approximately how many years did the Romans stay in this country?
tip: The Romans ruled Britain for almost 400 years, from AD 43 to AD 410.

question: The 'Swinging Sixties' is associated with the 1860s.
tip: The 'Swinging Sixties' refers to the 1960s. It was a period of rapid social change, including a growth in popular music and fashion. The Beatles and The Rolling Stones are associated with this period.

question: In 1588 the English fleet defeated a large French fleet of ships that intended to land an army in England.
tip: In 1588 the English fleet defeated the Spanish Armada fleet, which had been sent to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

question: Who was given the title of Lord Protector in the 17th century?
tip: Oliver Cromwell was appointed Lord Protector after the execution of King Charles I, when England was a republic without a king.

question: 'We shall fight them on the beaches' is a famous quote from a speech by Queen Elizabeth I about the Spanish Armada.
tip: We shall fight them on the beaches' is a quote from a speech by Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister in 1940, about a potential German invasion.

question: Which TWO of the following were British inventions?
tip: The television and jet engine are two of many important inventions by Britons in the 20th century.

question: When was the last successful invasion of England?
tip: The last successful invasion of England was in 1066 by William of Normandy.

question: Who were the 'suffragettes'?
options: Women who left the UK to live in India
Women who campaigned for women's votes
Women who chose to be single
Women who stayed at home to raise a family
tip: In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, an increasing number of women campaigned and demonstrated for women's rights, in particular the right to vote. They became known as 'suffragettes'.

question: Which TWO changes were introduced by the Education Act of 1944?
options: A clear division between primary and secondary education
tip: The Education Act of 1944 (also known as the Butler Education Act after the Minister of Education at the time, R A Butler) introduced free secondary education for all and established a clear division between the primary and secondary phases of education.

question: During the Victorian period the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen.
tip: The British Empire grew to cover India, Australia and large parts of Africa.

question: Before 1215 there were few limits on the power of the king of England.
tip: In 1215 King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to the Magna Carta, which limited the powers of the monarchy.

question: What was Isambard Kingdom Brunel famous for designing and building?
tip: Isambard Kingdom Brunel was a famous Victorian engineer who built railway lines, bridges, tunnels and ships.

question: Why is Henry VIII an important English monarch?
options: He broke from the Church of Rome.
He re-established the Catholic Church in England.
tip: Henry VIII broke from the Catholic Church of Rome when it refused him a divorce. He established his own church that became the Church of England.

question: In 1921 a treaty gave independence to the south of Ireland.
tip: The 1921 treaty led to Ireland being divided into two parts, Northern Ireland and the Irish Free State.

question: Britain has never been at war with France.
tip: Britain fought a number of wars with France during the Middle Ages and later.

question: Which TWO are associated with Sir Francis Drake?
tip: Sir Francis Drake was a famous Elizabethan sailor who took part in the defeat of the Spanish Armada and also successfully sailed around the world.

question: Of which product did the UK produce over half the world's supply in the 19th century?
tip: In the 19th century the UK produced more than half of the world's supplies of iron, coal and cotton cloth.

question: The Civil War between Charles I and Parliament in the mid-17th century led to Oliver Cromwell becoming king of England.
tip: At the end of the Civil War, England became a republic and Oliver Cromwell was made Lord Protector.

question: In 1707 the kingdoms of England and Scotland were united.
tip: The term Great Britain dates from the union in 1707 of England and Scotland.

question: King Henry VIII created the Church of England when the Pope refused to grant him a divorce.
tip: Henry broke away from the Roman Catholic Church so he could divorce his wife Catherine of Aragon and marry Anne Boleyn. He married six times in total and had one son.

question: Henry VII established the House of Tudor. What colour rose became the Tudor emblem?
tip: The Tudor rose was a red rose with a white rose inside it, showing the alliance between the Houses of York and Lancaster, who had previously fought against each other.

question: Shakespeare was a great English playwright.
tip: Shakespeare is regarded by many as the greatest playwright of all time.

question: In 1833 a law abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
tip: Parliament eventually passed the Emancipation Act that abolished slavery in 1833. William Wilberforce played an important part in changing the law.

question: Which TWO of the following were important 20th-century inventors?
tip: Alan Turing (1912–54) invented an early mathematical device that led to the development of the computer. Tim Berners-Lee (1955–) invented the World Wide Web.

question: The Union Flag consists of three crosses. One is St George's. Who do the other TWO crosses represent?
tip: The Union Flag comprises the crosses of Saints George, Andrew and Patrick.

question: D-Day refers to what event in British history?
options: Dropping of the atom bomb on Japan
End of the war in Europe in 1945
tip: D-Day refers to the allied invasion of Europe on 6 June 1944, which took place on the beaches of Normandy in France.

question: Henry VIII is famous for marrying six times and breaking away from the Church of Rome.
tip: Henry VIII had six wives and broke away from the Roman Catholic Church when the pope refused to grant him a divorce so he could marry again.

question: Margaret Thatcher was the longest-serving UK Prime Minister of the 20th century.
tip: Margaret Thatcher won her first General Election in 1979 and was re-elected in 1983 and 1987. She left office in 1990.

question: Which TWO points about slavery are correct?
options: William Wilberforce was a leading abolitionist.
Slavery survived in the British Empire until the early 20th century.
Quakers set up the first anti-slavery groups.
The Royal Navy refused to stop ships carrying slaves.
tip: William Wilberforce played an important role in ending slavery, which was eventually abolished in the British Empire in 1833. The Quakers set up the first anti-slavery groups in the late 1700s.

question: During the Great Depression of the 1930s the UK had high levels of employment.
tip: During the Great Depression of the 1930s, parts of the UK suffered mass unemployment.

question: Which TWO were great thinkers of the Enlightenment?
tip: Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics. David Hume wrote about human nature.

question: Who invaded England in 1066?
tip: In 1066, William of Normandy invaded England and defeated King Harold at the Battle of Hastings.

question: Which TWO of the following is William Shakespeare famous for writing?
tip: William Shakespeare (1564–1616) wrote many famous plays and poems. Many of his works are still performed today.

question: What happened to Margaret Thatcher in 1979 to make her famous in UK history?
options: She took part in the Olympics.
She became a High Court judge.
She became the first woman Prime Minister.
She was made a general in the British army.
tip: Margaret Thatcher became Britain's first woman Prime Minister in 1979 and won the next two elections in 1983 and 1987. She resigned as Prime Minister in 1990.

question: Hadrian's Wall was built to keep out whom?
tip: The Roman Emperor Hadrian built the wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

question: The Enlightenment led to major developments in which TWO areas?
tip: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, science and philosophy developed. This period became known as 'the Enlightenment'.

question: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11 November 1918.
tip: The ending of the First World War on 11 November 1918 is still commemorated to this day.

question: Which TWO groups contested the Wars of the Roses in the 15th century?
tip: A civil war known as the Wars of the Roses broke out in 1455 between supporters of the House of Lancaster and the House of York. It ended in 1485 at the Battle of Bosworth, when King Richard III of the House of York was killed.

question: What was the Beveridge Report of 1942 about?
options: How to end the war in Europe
How to treat the Germans and Japanese after the war
tip: The Beveridge Report of 1942, called Social Insurance and Allied Services, set out ideas on how to fight the five evils of Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness, and provided the basis of the modern welfare state.

question: Britain and Germany developed Concorde, a passenger supersonic aircraft.
tip: Concorde was a joint development with France, not Germany.

question: Catherine Howard was the sixth wife of Henry VIII.
tip: Catherine Howard, a cousin of Henry VIII's second wife, Anne Boleyn, was Henry's fifth wife.

question: What happened in 1215 to change the powers of the king?
tip: The Magna Carta was a charter drawn up by King John's noblemen. It laid down basic rights that still prevail today.

question: For which TWO reasons is Henry VIII remembered?
options: Broke away from the Church of Rome
tip: Henry VIII is famous for breaking away from the Catholic Church of Rome and marrying six times.

question: Pantomimes are plays based on fairy stories.
tip: Pantomime plays are a British tradition. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy.

question: The Brit Awards is an event where sports people are given awards.
tip: The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards to musicians in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

question: Some people rent land called 'an allotment', where they grow fruit and vegetables.
tip: Allotments are plots of land that can be rented for growing fruit and vegetables.

question: Which is the most popular sport in the UK?
tip: Football is the UK's most popular sport. It has a long history in the UK and the first professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century.

question: Most people in the UK live in towns and cities.
tip: Most people in the UK live in towns and cities but much of Britain is still countryside.

question: In the UK, 1 April is a day when people play jokes on each other.
tip: 1 April is known as April Fool's Day, when people play jokes on each other until midday.

question: Which TWO of the following are linked to football?
tip: The Premier League is the top league in English football and attracts a huge international audience. Many UK teams also compete in the UEFA (Union of European Football Associations) Champions League against other teams from Europe.

question: There are many variations in language in the different parts of the UK.
tip: The English language has many dialects and accents. In Wales many people speak Welsh. Gaelic is spoken in some parts of Scotland, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

question: Which of these is the name of a novel by Jane Austen?
tip: Jane Austen was an English novelist who wrote many books, including Sense and Sensibility and Pride and Prejudice.

question: What are Beowulf, The Tyger and She Walks in Beauty?
tip: Beowulf is an Anglo-Saxon poem, The Tyger is a poem by William Blake and She Walks in Beauty is a poem by Lord Byron.

question: Snowdonia is a national park in Northern Ireland.

question: In the UK a citizen may only follow an approved religion.
tip: Everyone has the legal right to choose their religion, or to choose not to practise a religion.

question: Dundee and Aberdeen are cities in Northern Ireland.
tip: Dundee and Aberdeen are cities in Scotland.

question: Which TWO events are religious festivals?
tip: Easter and Christmas are two Christian festivals. Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, and Easter marks his death on Good Friday and his rising from the dead on Easter Sunday.

question: The UK has a declining elderly population.
tip: The UK has an ageing population. People in the UK are living longer than ever before.

question: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent.
tip: Lent is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter. Traditionally, people would fast during this period and today many people will give something up, like a favourite food.

question: What do Sir William Golding, Seamus Heaney and Harold Pinter have in common?
options: They are all famous British athletes.
They have all been Prime Minister.
They were part of the first British expedition to the North Pole.
They have all been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.

question: What celebration takes place each year on 14 February?
tip: Valentine's Day is on 14 February each year, when lovers exchange cards and gifts.

question: Mo Farah and Jessica Ennis are well-known athletes who won gold medals at the 2012 London Olympics.
tip: Mo Farah won gold medals in the 5,000 and 10,000 metres, and Jessica Ennis won a gold medal in the heptathlon.

question: John Constable (1776–1837) founded the modern police force in England.
tip: John Constable was a famous British landscape painter.

question: Which TWO foods are associated with England?
