question: Thomas Hardy is a famous author who wrote Far from the Madding Crowd.
tip: Thomas Hardy (1840–1928) was a famous author and poet, whose best-known novels include Far from the Madding Crowd and Jude the Obscure.

question: What is the capital city of Wales?
tip: The capital city of Wales is Cardiff.

question: Charles Dickens is famous for writing musicals.
tip: Charles Dickens wrote a number of famous novels, including Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.

question: At which festival are mince pies traditionally eaten?
tip: Mince pies are traditionally eaten at Christmas time. People also eat roast turkey and Christmas pudding.

question: What task is associated with the National Trust?
tip: The National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and the National Trust for Scotland, work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside.

question: What is the highest-value note issued as British currency?
tip: The £50 note is the highest-value note in circulation. Other denominations (values) of British notes are £5, £10 and £20.

question: William Blake, Lord Byron and Robert Browning were all famous golfers.
tip: William Blake, Lord Byron and Robert Browning were all 19th-century poets.

question: The daffodil is the national flower of Wales.
tip: The daffodil is the national flower of Wales, and is worn on St David's Day.

question: Which is the capital city of the UK?
tip: The capital city of the UK is London, which is in England.

question: A traditional food in Wales is Ulster fry.
tip: An Ulster fry is a traditional food of Northern Ireland. It is a fried meal with bacon, eggs, sausage, black pudding, white pudding, tomatoes, mushrooms, soda bread and potato bread.

question: The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) is financed by selling advertising space during television programmes.
tip: The BBC is financed by funds raised from TV licences. Everyone in the UK with a television, computer or other medium which can be used for watching TV must have a television licence.

question: What type of church is the Church of Scotland?
tip: The Church of Scotland is a Presbyterian Church, and it is Scotland's national Church.

question: Bobby Moore is famous for his achievements in which sport?
tip: Bobby Moore was the captain of the England football team that won the World Cup in 1966.

question: Which sport can be traced back to 15th-century Scotland?
tip: The modern game of golf can be traced back to Scotland in the 15th century.

question: People over 75 years of age do not have to pay for a television licence.
tip: Everyone over 75 years of age can apply for a free television licence. Everyone in the UK with a television, computer or other medium which can be used for watching TV must have a television licence.

question: Which TWO plants are associated with the UK?
tip: The shamrock is the national flower of Northern Ireland, and the rose is the national flower of England.

question: In the UK betting and gambling are illegal.
tip: In the UK many people enjoy a gamble on sports or other events. You have to be over 18 to go into a betting shop or a gambling club.

question: The Lake District is England's largest national park.
tip: The Lake District is England's largest national park, covering 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres).

question: Since 1927 the BBC has organised which series of famous concerts?
tip: Since 1927 the BBC has sponsored and organised the annual Proms, an eight-week summer season of orchestral music.

question: During which part of the year are pantomime productions staged in theatres?
tip: Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences.

question: Which TWO members of a family have a special day dedicated to them?
tip: In the UK Mothering Sunday is celebrated on the Sunday three weeks before Easter and Father's Day on the third Sunday in June. Children send cards and give gifts on these days.

question: Most people live in the countryside in the UK.
tip: Most people in the UK live in towns and cities, but much of Britain is still countryside.

question: The Crown Jewels are kept at the Tower of London.
tip: You can see the Crown Jewels at the Tower of London. The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066.

question: The Wimbledon Championships are associated with motor sports.
tip: The Wimbledon Championships are associated with tennis.

question: Which TWO are famous British authors?
tip: Thomas Hardy was an author and poet, whose novels include Far from the Madding Crowd and Jude the Obscure. Graham Greene wrote many novels including The Heart of the Matter, The Honorary Consul, Brighton Rock and Our Man in Havana.

question: Boys in the UK leave school with better qualifications than girls.
tip: On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. Also, more women than men study at university.

question: Why is Sir Edwin Lutyens famous?
options: He won a gold medal at the London 2012 Olympic Games.
He was the first UK Prime Minister.
He invented the World Wide Web.
tip: Sir Edwin Lutyens was a famous 20th-century architect who designed the Cenotaph in Whitehall.

question: Cardiff, Swansea and Newport are cities in England.
tip: Cardiff, Swansea and Newport are all cities in Wales.

question: UK population growth has been faster in recent years.
tip: UK population growth has been faster in recent years, due to migration into the UK and longer life expectancy.

question: Which TWO are famous British composers?
tip: Henry Purcell wrote church music, opera and other pieces, and developed a distinctive British style. Ralph Vaughan Williams was strongly influenced by traditional English folk music.

question: What is a traditional pub game in the UK?
tip: Pool is a traditional pub game, along with darts. Pub quizzes are also popular. Many communities have a local pub that is a natural focal point for social activities.

question: You can support your local community by becoming a school governor or school board member.
tip: Being a school governor or school board member is a voluntary, unpaid activity. These roles play an important part in raising school standards.

question: The British constitution is contained in a single written document.
tip: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.

question: In 1999, what happened to hereditary peers in the House of Lords?
options: Women were allowed to inherit their titles.
They lost their automatic right to attend the House of Lords.
tip: Hereditary peers are members of the House of Lords who have inherited their titles. In 1999 they lost their automatic right to attend and now only a few are left.

question: The National Citizen Service provides military training to young people.
tip: The National Citizen Service gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

question: Which TWO of the following do pressure and lobby groups do?
options: Assist MPs in their constituency work
Represent the views of British businesses
tip: Pressure groups and lobby groups play an important part in the UK political process. Groups such as the Confederation of British Industry (CBI – which represents British business) and Greenpeace (which is concerned about environmental issues) lobby politicians to get their views across.

question: What important change to our voting rights took place in 1969?
options: Women over 35 were given the vote.
The voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.
tip: In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

question: How are local councils funded?
options: Through money raised from local fundraising events
From central government and local taxes
tip: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by democratically elected councils, often called 'local authorities'. These are funded by money from central government and by local taxes.

question: Members of the public are allowed to attend Youth Court hearings.
tip: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

question: The Scottish Parliament can pass legislation for Scotland on all matters.
tip: The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters that are not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament.

question: At what age can you vote in a General Election in the UK?
tip: The present voting age is 18, and was set in 1969.

question: Where is the National Assembly for Wales based?
tip: The National Assembly for Wales is based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales.

question: The main political parties actively look for members.
tip: The main political parties actively look for members of the public to join their debates, contribute to their costs, and help at elections.

question: How often are elections for the European Parliament held?
tip: Elections for the European Parliament are held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs).

question: How often are members of Parliament (MPs) elected?
tip: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

question: A husband who forces his wife to have sex can be charged with rape.
tip: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman's husband, can be charged with rape.

question: If a person is aged under 21, their case will be heard in a Youth Court.
tip: If an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally held in a Youth Court.

question: How old do you need to be in order to stand for public office?
tip: Citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth must be aged 18 or over to stand for public office.

question: Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence in the UK.
tip: Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership. This is a criminal offence in the UK.

question: Which TWO of the following issues can the Northern Ireland Assembly make decisions on?
tip: The Northern Ireland Assembly can make decisions on various issues, including agriculture and social services.

question: What system of government does the UK have?
tip: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies, and voters in each constituency elect a member of Parliament (MP) to represent them.

question: When a member of Parliament (MP) dies or resigns, what is the election called that is held to replace them?
tip: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a by-election in his or her constituency to elect a new MP.

question: Who has to pay National Insurance Contributions?
options: Everybody in the UK who is in paid work
tip: Almost everyone in paid work, including the self-employed, have to pay National Insurance Contributions (NICs). The contributions help pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

question: Getting to know your neighbours can help you to become part of the community.
tip: Getting to know your neighbours can help you to become part of the community and make friends. Your neighbours are also a good source of help.

question: If your car is more than three years old, how often will it need a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test?
tip: If your car is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. If the vehicle is new, it will need an MOT test after three years, and then every year.

question: All young people are sent a National Insurance number just before their 16th birthday.
tip: All young people in the UK are sent a National Insurance number just before their 16th birthday. It ensures that the National Insurance Contributions and tax you pay are properly recorded against your name.

question: Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland each have devolved administrations which give them total control over all policies and laws.
tip: Some powers have been devolved from central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. Some policy and laws remain under central UK government control.

question: Which TWO things can you do to look after the environment?
options: Drive your car as much as possible
Never turn the lights off in your house
Walk and use public transport to get around
tip: Recycle as much of your waste as you can, as this will reduce the amount of rubbish in landfill sites. Walking and using public transport creates less pollution than using a car.

question: What is a jury made up of?
options: People randomly chosen from the electoral register
People who are members of political parties
People who have submitted an application form and been accepted
tip: A jury is made up of members of the public chosen at random from the electoral register.

question: How many people serve on a jury in Scotland?
tip: In Scotland a jury has 15 members. In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members.

question: Which TWO of the following groups of adults are eligible to vote in all UK elections?
options: Only those born in the UK
Citizens of the Commonwealth who are resident in the UK
tip: UK-born and naturalised adult citizens, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all UK elections. (Adult citizens of other EU states who are resident in the UK can vote in all elections except General Elections.)

question: How can you reduce your carbon footprint?
options: Buy duty-free products when you're abroad
tip: Shopping locally for products will reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

question: Members of the armed forces cannot stand for public office.
tip: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic and the Commonwealth can stand for public office. There are some exceptions, including members of the armed forces.

question: What are TWO benefits of volunteering?
options: You are given a courtesy car as transport
Making your community a better place
tip: Volunteering is working for good causes without payment. There are many benefits to volunteering, including meeting new people and making your community a better place.

question: You can serve on a jury up to the age of 80.
tip: The age limit for jury service is 70. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do jury service.

question: Which TWO of the following are part of the UK government?
tip: There are several different parts of government in the UK, which include the cabinet and the civil service.

question: In the 1830s and 1840s a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform to the voting system.
tip: The Chartists campaigned for reform of the voting system. The changes they wanted included annual elections and for all regions to be equal in the electoral system.

question: The court systems in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland are identical.
tip: There are some differences between the systems of courts in different parts of the UK.

question: What happens when members of Parliament (MPs) hold surgeries?
options: They meet local councillors to discuss local issues.
Members of the public can meet their MP to discuss issues.
They discuss local health issues with doctors.
They invite members of the press along to talk over national issues.
tip: MPs hold regular 'surgeries', where constituents can go in person to talk about issues that are of concern to them.

question: If you are a Commonwealth citizen living in the UK you can vote in all public elections.
tip: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections.

question: Which TWO courts deal with minor criminal cases in the UK?
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

question: What must police officers do?
tip: Police officers must obey the law. They must not be rude or abusive, make a false statement, misuse their authority, or commit racial discrimination.

question: Who do some local councils appoint as a ceremonial leader?
options: A member of the Royal Family
tip: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. (However in some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.)

question: The Home Secretary is the government minister responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries.
tip: The Home Secretary is the government minister responsible for prevention of crime, policing and immigration.

question: What is one of the roles of school governors and school boards?
options: Setting the strategic direction of the school
Giving teachers ideas for lesson plans
Serving food and drink in the canteen
tip: School governors and school boards have an important part to play in raising school standards. This includes setting the strategic direction of the school.

question: What is the minimum age for jury service?
tip: Anyone on the electoral register aged between 18 and 70 can be asked to serve on a jury.

question: Pressure and lobby groups try to influence British government policy.
tip: Pressure groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics and the democratic process.

question: An example of a civil law case is when you have purchased a faulty item and made a legal complaint.
tip: Civil law cases relate to disputes between individuals or groups.

question: How is the Speaker of the House of Commons chosen?
tip: The Speaker is chosen by other members of Parliament (MPs) in a secret ballot. The Speaker's role is to chair debates in the House of Commons.

question: Which of the following do you need in order to gain a full car licence?
options: Pass a driving test which tests both knowledge and practical skills
tip: You have to pass both a theory and a practical driving test before you are given a full driving licence.

question: What happens when a member of Parliament (MP) dies or resigns?
options: The post remains vacant until the next General Election.
Their party chooses someone to fill the post until the next General Election.
A by-election is held to replace the MP.
A neighbouring MP looks after the constituency.
tip: When an MP dies or resigns, a by-election is held. This is an election held in that constituency to elect a new MP.

question: The House of Lords always acts as the government wishes.
tip: The House of Lords is normally more independent of government than the House of Commons.

question: A General Election occurs every eight years.
tip: General Elections in the UK are held at least every five years.

question: Which parts of the United Kingdom have devolved governments?
tip: Some powers have been devolved from central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them.

question: What age group does the National Citizen Service programme cover?
options: All children up to the age of 17
tip: The National Citizen Service programme is aimed at 16- and 17-year-olds. It gives them the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

question: The devolved Scottish government rules Scotland from Edinburgh.
tip: The Scottish Parliament sits in Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland.

question: Life peers in the House of Lords can pass on their title to their first-born child.
tip: Most members of the House of Lords are now life peers, who are nominated by the Prime Minister and appointed by the monarch to sit in the House of Lords for their own lifetime.

question: People are able to buy National Lottery tickets in the UK if they are aged 14 or over.
tip: People under 16 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery.

question: In the UK you are expected to respect the rights of others to have their own opinions.
tip: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include respecting the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions.

question: What TWO freedoms are offered by the UK to citizens and permanent residents?
options: A right to a fair trial
tip: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. This includes freedom of speech and a right to a fair trial.

question: British values and principles are based on history and traditions.
tip: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles, which are based on history and traditions and are protected by law, customs and expectations.

question: There is no place in British society for extremism or intolerance.
tip: There is no place for extremism or intolerance. British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK respect and support.

question: Participating in your community is a fundamental principle of British life.
tip: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support. This includes participating in community life.

question: To apply for UK citizenship or permanent residency, which TWO things do you need?
options: An ability to speak and read English
A good understanding of life in the UK
tip: To apply to become a UK citizen or permanent resident, you must be able to speak and read English and have a good understanding of life in the UK.

question: What is a responsibility that you will have as a citizen or permanent resident of the UK?
options: To keep your dog on a lead at all times
To avoid shopping on a Sunday
To look after yourself and your family
tip: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include looking after yourself and your family.

question: Which is a fundamental principle of British life?
options: Actively supporting your local football team
tip: Participation in community life is a fundamental principle of British life. British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support.

question: In the UK you are expected to treat others with fairness.
tip: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include treating others with fairness.

question: All citizens and permanent residents of the UK can choose which laws they follow.
tip: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include respecting and obeying the law.

question: Which of the following is a Crown dependency?
tip: The Channel Islands are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it, and have their own governments.

question: What countries does 'Great Britain' refer to?
tip: 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland. The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

question: Which of the following is a British overseas territory?
tip: There are several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as the Falkland Islands.

question: St Helena is a Crown dependency.
tip: St Helena is a British overseas territory and not a Crown dependency.

question: The Channel Islands are a part of the UK.
tip: The Channel Islands are not a part of the UK but are closely linked to it. They have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'.

question: The Isle of Man is a Crown dependency.
tip: Like the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man is a Crown dependency with its own government.

question: The Republic of Ireland is part of the UK.
tip: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland make up the UK.

question: Which TWO of the following are part of the UK?
tip: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland make up the UK.

question: Where is the UK parliament based?
tip: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.

question: The Channel Islands have their own governments.
tip: The Channel Islands have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'.

question: 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales.
tip: 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.
